content.description:
Thin fun climbing up the right side of the arete.

Starts of with the techy face stuff to a bulge. Power thru the bulge on small crimps and sidepulls,  then move into the 2nd crux, a balancey move on bad feet into a high side pull.
content.location: Around the corner from Teardrop on the right side of the wall. 2nd to last route on the right.

climbs.name: Three Amigos
climbs.fa: Jeff Pederson, Boone Speed and Vince Adams

content.description: A technical climb up thin edges.  Starts 2/3 of the way up the 4th class ramp in the large corner area.  Crux is around the third bolt; don't be afraid to wander a little bit.
content.location: Just left of Cannabis Crack in the middle of the face

content.description:
Start on 4th class climbing to the first bolt. Slightly overhanging from there. Mid eleven climbing starts immediately after clipping the first bolt. Interesting movement on sidepulls.

Technical crux starts after clipping 6th bolt. Redpoint crux is after clipping 7th. Pull through that and it's jugs to the 8th bolt and anchors.
content.protection: 8 bolts with fixed draws. Two anchors with draws up top.
content.location: Noticeable fixed line of draws that goes straight up above the 4th class bottom. Jug Abuse (also fixed draws) branches left after 3rd bolt.

content.description: A harder variation of Merciless Onslaught. Climb tiny holds on perfect rock. At bolt 4 the angle kicks back to less tenous and easier moves.

Second route from the left.  Climbs up a small crack to a roof; pulling it is the crux.  Follow three more bolts on slabs to a ledge and the anchors.  Chossy.

Feels quite a bit easier than Electric Company to the right.
content.protection: The Ruckman guide says 6, but there are 8 bolts, I think.

content.description:
A fun line with two somewhat tricky sections.

Straightforward from the ground to clipping the first bolt, then a bit devious and thin through the third bolt. A bit of a respite, followed by a head-scratching roof that requires balance and a bit of commitment.

After the roof, find your way to a ledge, followed by a bit more tricky climbing to the chains.
content.protection: 8 bolts, chain anchors. Last bolt is poorly positioned and will load the top biner over an edge.
content.location:
The second-from-left bolted line, although it will appear as the left-most, because the actual left-most line is hidden from view in a corner at the extreme left of the crag.

Another way of looking at it is that this route is the line to the left of the large evergreen tree that leans in toward the wall at the left side of the crag (the line directly opposite the tree is

Sesame Street

).

Note also that this line isn't shown in the Ruckman guide.

content.description: Leftmost route at Cannabis.  Starts in an open book corner, then goes up an arete, then traverses right.  You'll see the anchors for Scooby Snack.  Stay to the left of them and head up a short, but fun flake/crack that you can hand jam.  Finally head out left to the 1st set of anchors.  I didn't do the second pitch.  A 60m will allow you to rap to the ground.  Probably want a second to clean the route as it was a pain to swing over to get the draws on rap.  I'd minimally recommend using a 3rd hand if you do.
content.protection: Draws, healthily spaced, be sure you are solid at the grade

content.description:
Originally bolted in 1990 or 91 (Scott Franklin) and abandoned. The start was bolted close to Underdog. New start was bolted in 2011, connecting with the upper section of the original line. Nearly all bolts and anchors were moved and replaced.

Tricky boulder problem at the bottom to a big hold rest, then continuous hard moves to the anchors.

Bouldery start on crimps on the arete.  Clip two more bolts on the right of the arete, then rest up for the thin traverse through the fourth bolt.  I thought this was the crux.  Shares two bolts and an anchor with Three Amigos.
content.protection: Six bolts to chains.  Stick clipping the first bolt wouldn't be a bad idea.
content.location: On the arete down from Three Amigos and Cannabis Crack

content.description: The first 4 bolts are kind of technical and powerful and then the climbing gets easier. It is an excellent route! One of the best 12b's up American Fork. This route is just right of Electric Company and shares anchors with it.
This is a powerful route with a desperate hard finish at the top. Lots of gaston moves!
content.location: This route starts up the slab and heads left. It branches off of Teardrop at the third bolt.

content.description: Located after the first small roof climbing eases off. Good rock. A little dusty still but will clean up with ascents.
content.location: Lower cannabis, river level. Follows the black/blue streak trending right to left.

content.description:
Best climb of the grade at the wall.  Climbs a slab for three bolts to an overhanging, flared crack.  Use fingerlocks(!) or interesting liebacks to fire the steepness to a sweet pinch and tough clip, then up and left to a tricky top-out.  Very satisfying.

Be wary of loose stuff on this route, I saw a belayer get nailed in the thigh by a fist-sized rock.
content.location: Rightmost climb on the wall.  Shares the start with the .13a to the left.  First bolt is up 25 feet or so.

content.description: Third route from the left.  Climbs through a couple horizontal ledges using pockets and crimps.  Fun route; crux is after the third bolt.

Start with some easy climbing to reach the high first bolt.  Clip the first 2 bolts on Field of Screams, trending right.  Interesting techy climbing  on positive crimps.  At the last bolt, trend left using undercling flakes to reach the anchor out to the right.  Not a bad warm up for some of the harder routes here.
content.location: Just to the right of Field of Screams, 12a.  Shares the same start.

content.description: Jams, crimps and stemming gets you up the obvious crack below the big roof.  Trends left, eventually finishing with some liebacking below the roof.  Crux is probably turning the corner just before the anchors.
content.protection: 5 bolts to chain anchors.  There is also sufficient gear to make it a trad climb, but who brings their rack to AF?
